panels.description:
This chart displays the current count of online streams

Metric: The metric being tracked is the number of streams that are currently in the 'ONLINE' state. This indicates that these streams are actively receiving data and functioning as expected.

Time Frame: The count is based on streams that have had activity within the last 10 seconds. This ensures that the data reflects the most recent status of the streams.

The data is sourced from the network_events.stream_status table, which contains the current state and last input time for each stream.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT COUNT(*) AS online_count
FROM network_events.stream_status
WHERE state = 'ONLINE' AND
      last_input_time_ts >= now() - INTERVAL 10 SECOND;

panels.title: Online Streams

panels.description:
This dashboard show the average of stream start-up time that is successful in seconds.

Green = Avg < 6 seconds
Yellow = Avg 6 - 10 seconds
Red = Avg > 12 seconds.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
  toFloat64(median(source.total_time_diff_ms)) / 1000.0 AS `Start Up Time Seconds`
FROM
  (
    SELECT
      network_events.stream_trace_summary.total_time_diff_ms AS total_time_diff_ms
    FROM
      network_events.stream_trace_summary
    WHERE
      $__timeFilter(first_event_timestamp_ts)
  ) AS source

panels.title: Average Start Up Time

panels.description:
This chart indicates the percentage of streams that experience errors.

Green = < 10% of streams with errors

Yellow = > 10% of streams with errors

Red = > 20% of streams with errors

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
  SUM(CASE WHEN last_error_time_ts IS NOT NULL THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) / COUNT(*) * 100 AS `Error Percentage`
FROM (
  SELECT
    stream_id,
    MAX(last_error_time_ts) AS last_error_time_ts
  FROM
    network_events.stream_status
  WHERE
    $__timeFilter(timestamp_ts)
  GROUP BY
    stream_id
) AS stream_errors

panels.title: Streams W/Errors

panels.description: This monitors the full start up success rate.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
  CASE
    WHEN count() > 0 THEN SUM(
      CASE
        WHEN source.gateway_startup_completed = 1 THEN 1
        ELSE 0
      END
    )
    ELSE NULL
  END / COUNT(*) AS `Gateway Start Up Success`
FROM
  (
    SELECT
      network_events.stream_trace_summary.gateway_startup_completed AS gateway_startup_completed
    FROM
      network_events.stream_trace_summary
    WHERE
      $__timeFilter(first_event_timestamp_ts)
  ) AS source

panels.title: Gateway Start Up Success Rate

panels.description: Provides information on the number of AI livestreams currently live in staging.
panels.title: Total Stream Counts

panels.description:
The chart show the average number of seconds spent for each of the event.
- gateway_recieve

targets.rawSql:
WITH all_subtypes AS (
    SELECT 'app_receive_first_segment' AS sub_type
    UNION ALL SELECT 'gateway_recieve_stream_request' AS sub_type
    UNION ALL SELECT 'gateway_send_first_ingest_segment' AS sub_type
    UNION ALL SELECT 'runner_receive_first_ingest_segment' AS sub_type
)
SELECT
  `all_subtypes`.`sub_type` AS `sub_type`,
  COALESCE(`toFloat64`(AVG(`filtered_data`.`time_diff_ms`)) / 1000.0, 0) AS `Average of Time Seconds`
FROM
  all_subtypes
LEFT JOIN
  (
    SELECT
      `network_events`.`stream_trace`.`sub_type` AS `sub_type`,
      `network_events`.`stream_trace`.`time_diff_ms` AS `time_diff_ms`
    FROM
      `network_events`.`stream_trace`
    WHERE
      (`network_events`.`stream_trace`.`sub_type` = 'app_receive_first_segment'
      OR `network_events`.`stream_trace`.`sub_type` = 'gateway_recieve_stream_request'
      OR `network_events`.`stream_trace`.`sub_type` = 'gateway_send_first_ingest_segment'
      OR `network_events`.`stream_trace`.`sub_type` = 'runner_receive_first_ingest_segment')
      AND `network_events`.`stream_trace`.`timestamp_ts` >= toDateTime($__from/1000)
      AND `network_events`.`stream_trace`.`timestamp_ts` <= toDateTime($__to/1000)
  ) AS `filtered_data` ON `all_subtypes`.`sub_type` = `filtered_data`.`sub_type`
GROUP BY
  `all_subtypes`.`sub_type`
ORDER BY
  `all_subtypes`.`sub_type` ASC

panels.title: Start Up Time

panels.description: The chart shows the sub-type with stream Ids of the time spent for each of the event.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
  `source`.`timestamp` AS `timestamp`,
  `source`.`event_timestamp_ts` AS `event_timestamp_ts`,
  `source`.`stream_id` AS `stream_id`,
  `source`.`sub_type` AS `sub_type`,
  `source`.`time_diff_ms` AS `time_diff_ms`,
  `source`.`request_id` AS `request_id`,
  `source`.`Pipelines__name` AS `Pipelines__name`,
  `source`.`pipeline_id` AS `pipeline_id`,
  `source`.`event_timestamp` AS `event_timestamp`,
  `source`.`last_timestamp` AS `last_timestamp`,
  `source`.`event_order` AS `event_order`,
  `source`.`orch_address` AS `orch_address`,
  `source`.`orch_url` AS `orch_url`,
  `source`.`Pipelines__key` AS `Pipelines__key`,
  `source`.`Pipelines__author` AS `Pipelines__author`
FROM
  (
    SELECT
      `network_events`.`stream_trace`.`timestamp` AS `timestamp`,
      `network_events`.`stream_trace`.`event_timestamp_ts` AS `event_timestamp_ts`,
      `network_events`.`stream_trace`.`sub_type` AS `sub_type`,
      `network_events`.`stream_trace`.`stream_id` AS `stream_id`,
      `network_events`.`stream_trace`.`request_id` AS `request_id`,
      `network_events`.`stream_trace`.`pipeline_id` AS `pipeline_id`,
      `network_events`.`stream_trace`.`event_timestamp` AS `event_timestamp`,
      `network_events`.`stream_trace`.`last_timestamp` AS `last_timestamp`,
      `network_events`.`stream_trace`.`event_order` AS `event_order`,
      `network_events`.`stream_trace`.`orch_address` AS `orch_address`,
      `network_events`.`stream_trace`.`orch_url` AS `orch_url`,
      `network_events`.`stream_trace`.`time_diff_ms` AS `time_diff_ms`,
      `Pipelines`.`key` AS `Pipelines__key`,
      `Pipelines`.`name` AS `Pipelines__name`,
      `Pipelines`.`author` AS `Pipelines__author`
    FROM
      `network_events`.`stream_trace`
     
LEFT JOIN `network_events`.`pipelines` AS `Pipelines` ON `network_events`.`stream_trace`.`pipeline_id` = `Pipelines`.`id`
  ) AS `source`
WHERE
  (
    `source`.`sub_type` = 'gateway_send_first_ingest_segment'
    OR `source`.`sub_type` = 'runner_receive_first_ingest_segment'
    OR `source`.`sub_type` = 'gateway_recieve_stream_request'
  )
 
   AND (
    `source`.`event_timestamp_ts` >= toDateTime($__from/1000)
  )
  AND (
    `source`.`event_timestamp_ts` < toDateTime($__to/1000)
  )
  AND (`source`.`Pipelines__key` = 'comfyui')
  AND `source`.`stream_id` IN (${stream_id:singlequote})

panels.title: Start Up Time with Stream Id

panels.description:
This visualizes the count of'restart' and 'error' events for the latest 15 distinct streams in the network_events.stream_events dataset.
It identifies streams with the number of restarts and errors.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT stream_id, 
countIf(event_type = 'restart') AS restart_count, 
countIf(event_type = 'error') AS error_count
FROM 
    network_events.stream_events
WHERE 
    sub_type IN ('error', 'restart')
    AND stream_id IN (${stream_id:singlequote})
    AND $__timeFilter(timestamp_ts)
group by 1

panels.title: Stream Error/Restart Count by Stream ID

panels.description: This chart displays the most recent events related to errors and restarts within the streaming system.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
    stream_id, 
    timestamp_ts,
    restart_count,
    event_type, 
    message, 
    gateway,
    type, 
    capability, 
    pipeline, 
    pipeline_id, 
    params, 
    orchestrator_address, 
    orchestrator_url
FROM 
    network_events.stream_events
WHERE 
    sub_type IN ('error', 'restart')
    AND stream_id IN (${stream_id:singlequote})
    AND $__timeFilter(timestamp_ts)
    AND pipeline = 'comfyui'
ORDER BY 
    timestamp_ts DESC
LIMIT 100;

panels.title: Stream Logs

panels.description: Log information of all the streams of selected streams during the gateway process.
panels.title: Gateway Stream Logs

panels.description: Log information of all the streams of selected streams during the MediaMTX process.
panels.title: MediaMTX Logs

panels.description:
This chart visualizes the CPU usage percentage for nodes in specified regions, with a threshold set at 80%.

A CPU usage percentage greater than 80% indicates that the system is heavily loaded, with most of the CPU resources actively in use.

targets.expr: 100 - (avg by (instance, region) (irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{region=~"${region:regex}", mode="idle", instance=~".+:9100"}[1m])) * 100 * on(instance) group_left(nodename) node_uname_info)

panels.title: CPU Usage

panels.description:
This chart visualizes the CPU usage percentage for nodes in specified regions, with a threshold set at 50%.

A CPU usage percentage greater than 50% indicates that more than half of the CPU resources are actively being utilized.
panels.title: CPU Memory Usage (> 50%)

panels.description:
This  indicates how much of the total disk capacity is being utilized.

A higher percentage indicates that a significant portion of the disk space is in use, which may suggest that the filesystem is nearing capacity.
panels.title: Disk Usage

panels.description:
This shows the disk I/O performance for various regions, specifically focusing on the rates of data being written to and read from disk.

Normal Operation:-
When the disk write and read rates are within expected ranges based on usage over time , the system is functioning normally. You should see stable lines on the graph, indicating consistent disk I/O performance.

High Disk Write/Read Rates:- If the lines show significantly high values, it may indicate heavy disk usage. This could be due data ingestion processes. 

Sudden spikes or drops in disk I/O can indicate issues that need further investigation of the node
panels.title: Ingest Disk I/O Per Minute

panels.description: This shows the number of GPUs online. i.e that are actively running and reporting power metrics
panels.title: GPUs

panels.description: This graph indicates the number of streams running per orchestrator.
panels.title: Streams per Orchestrator

panels.description: Monitoring VRAM usage helps ensure that tasks aren't running out of memory, which can cause significant performance degradation or crashes. It's important to know if the GPU's memory is sufficient for the tasks or if you need to scale up.
panels.title: GPU Memory Usage

panels.description: This is crucial to understand how effectively the GPU is being used. High utilization is good for performance but could indicate potential bottlenecks if consistently at 100%. Low utilization might suggest that the GPU is oversized for the task or there's an inefficiency in workload distribution.
panels.title: GPU Utilization

panels.description: This number indicates the average output of FPS.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
  AVG(`source`.`avg`) AS `avg`
FROM
  (
    SELECT
      `network_events`.`stream_status`.`stream_id` AS `stream_id`,
      AVG(`network_events`.`stream_status`.`output_fps`) AS `avg`
    FROM
      `network_events`.`stream_status`
   
GROUP BY
      `network_events`.`stream_status`.`stream_id`
   
ORDER BY
      `network_events`.`stream_status`.`stream_id` ASC
  ) AS `source`

panels.title: AVG FPS Output

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
  `network_events`.`stream_status`.`stream_id` AS `stream_id`,
  AVG(`network_events`.`stream_status`.`output_fps`) AS `avg`
FROM
  `network_events`.`stream_status`
WHERE
  (
    `network_events`.`stream_status`.`timestamp_ts` >= `toStartOfHour`((`now64`(9, 'UTC') + INTERVAL -24 hour))
  )
  AND (
    `network_events`.`stream_status`.`timestamp_ts` < `toStartOfHour`((`now64`(9, 'UTC') + INTERVAL 1 hour))
  )
  AND (
    `network_events`.`stream_status`.`pipeline` = 'comfyui'
  )
  AND (
    `network_events`.`stream_status`.`stream_id` IN (${stream_id:singlequote})
  )
GROUP BY
  `network_events`.`stream_status`.`stream_id`
ORDER BY
  `avg` ASC;

panels.description:
This table displays the number of errors for each type that is being reported.

Green = below 20 errors
Yellow = 20 - 50 errors
Red = > 50 errors

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
  `source`.`stream_id` AS `stream_id`,
  `source`.`short_message` AS `short_message`,
  COUNT(*) AS `count`
FROM
  (
    SELECT
      `network_events`.`stream_events`.`sub_type` AS `sub_type`,
      `network_events`.`stream_events`.`timestamp_ts` AS `timestamp_ts`,
      `network_events`.`stream_events`.`message` AS `message`,
      `network_events`.`stream_events`.`stream_id` AS `stream_id`,
      `substring`(
        `toString`(`network_events`.`stream_events`.`message`),
        1,
        70
      ) AS `short_message`
    FROM
      `network_events`.`stream_events`
    WHERE
      `network_events`.`stream_events`.`sub_type` = 'error'
      AND $__timeFilter(timestamp_ts)
      AND `network_events`.`stream_events`.`stream_id` IN (${stream_id:sqlstring})
      AND pipeline = 'comfyui'
  ) AS `source`
WHERE
  `source`.`short_message` != ''
GROUP BY
  `source`.`short_message`,
  `source`.`stream_id`
ORDER BY
  count DESC;

panels.title: Error Count by Type

panels.description:
This chart displays the distinct types of stream errors that occurs most frequently, along with their corresponding counts.

0-5 counts: Needs Minor Attention

4-9 counts: Needs Medium Attention

10 or more counts: Needs Urgent Attention

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
  `source`.`short_message` AS `short_message`,
  COUNT(*) AS `count`
FROM
  (
    SELECT
      `network_events`.`stream_events`.`sub_type` AS `sub_type`,
      `network_events`.`stream_events`.`timestamp_ts` AS `timestamp_ts`,
      `network_events`.`stream_events`.`message` AS `message`,
      `substring`(
        `toString`(`network_events`.`stream_events`.`message`),
        1,
        70
      ) AS `short_message`
    FROM
      `network_events`.`stream_events`
    WHERE
      `network_events`.`stream_events`.`sub_type` = 'error'
      AND $__timeFilter(timestamp_ts)
      AND pipeline = 'comfyui'
  ) AS `source`
WHERE
  `source`.`short_message` != ''
GROUP BY
  `source`.`short_message`
ORDER BY
  count DESC;

panels.title: Error count by type

panels.description: This chart displays the most recent events related to errors in the inference process.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT stream_id, timestamp_ts, event_type, pipeline, pipeline_id, message, gateway, type, capability, params, orchestrator_address, orchestrator_url
FROM network_events.stream_events
WHERE sub_type IN ('error', 'restart')
AND stream_id IN (${stream_id:singlequote})
AND $__timeFilter(timestamp_ts)
AND pipeline = 'comfyui'
ORDER BY timestamp_ts DESC LIMIT 100;

panels.title: Inference  Logs

panels.description: Log information of all the streams of selected streams during the inference process. Using {container="live-video-to-video_comfyui_8900"}
panels.title: Inference Stream Logs

panels.description: This table contains information on the stream and the pipeline it is using.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
    stream_status.stream_id,
    timestamp_ts,
    Streams.id AS `Streams__id`,
    Streams.pipeline_id AS `Streams__pipeline_id`,
    Streams.output_playback_id AS `Streams__output_playback_id`,
    Streams.author AS `Streams__author`,
    Streams.stream_key AS `Streams__stream_key`,
    Streams.output_stream_url AS `Streams__output_stream_url`,
    Streams.created_at AS `Streams__created_at`,
    Streams.pipeline_params AS `Streams__pipeline_params`,
    Streams.from_playground AS `Streams__from_playground`,
    Streams.gateway_host AS `Streams__gateway_host`,
    Pipelines.id AS `Pipelines__id`,
    Pipelines.name AS `Pipelines__name`,
    Pipelines.version AS `Pipelines__version`,
    Pipelines.description AS `Pipelines__description`,
    Pipelines.author AS `Pipelines__author`,
    Pipelines.type AS `Pipelines__type`,
    Pipelines.created_at AS `Pipelines__created_at`,
    Pipelines.updated_at AS `Pipelines__updated_at`
FROM network_events.stream_status
    LEFT JOIN network_events.streams AS Streams ON stream_status.stream_id = Streams.id
    LEFT JOIN network_events.pipelines AS Pipelines ON stream_status.pipeline_id = Pipelines.id
    LEFT JOIN network_events.users AS `Users - Author` ON Pipelines.author = `Users - Author`.id
WHERE $__timeFilter(timestamp_ts) 
AND stream_status.stream_id IN (${stream_id:singlequote})
AND pipeline = 'comfyui'
ORDER BY timestamp_ts ASC;

panels.title: Stream's Pipeline Data

panels.description:
This measures the power consumption of the GPU. This metric helps to understand the energy efficiency and operational costs associated with the GPU usage

450W :- This is the maximum power that the GPU can draw

315W :- This is the average consumption of the GPU when running a job

19 W :- This is the amount of power the GPU consumes when it is not actively being used
panels.title: GPU Power Usage

panels.description:
This indicates the current temperature of the GPU.  It assess the thermal performance and health of the GPU, as elevated temperatures can indicate potential overheating issues

Idle Temperature 30°C - 50°C 

Load Temperature 70°C - 85°C 

Maximum Safe Temperature 90°C - 100°C
panels.title: GPU Temperature

panels.description:
2520 MHz (Boost Clock Speed):
This is the maximum clock speed that the GPU can achieve under optimal conditions, known as the boost clock speed. It represents the peak performance capability of the RTX 4090 when the GPU is under heavy load and has adequate cooling and power supply. Monitoring this value helps us understand the upper limits of the GPU's performance during demanding tasks.

2235 MHz (Base Clock Speed):
This is the minimum clock speed at which the GPU operates under normal conditions. The base clock speed indicates the performance level the GPU should maintain during standard workloads. If the SM clock speed consistently operates at or near this value, it is functioning as expected. Monitoring this value helps ensure that the GPU is performing adequately during typical usage scenarios.

2000 MHz (Threshold for Concern):
This is the threshold we have set to identify potential performance issues. If the SM clock speed drops below 2000 MHz during demanding tasks, it may indicate that the GPU is experiencing problems such as thermal throttling (overheating), power limitations, or other issues that could affect performance. Monitoring for values below this threshold allows us to take proactive measures to investigate and resolve any underlying issues before they impact the overall performance of the GPU.

Note: The mean value on the chart should also be taking a close look at. Drop below 2000 MHz during demanding tasks may indicate issues such as thermal throttling, power limitations, or driver problems
panels.title: SM Clock Speed

panels.description:
This indicates the utilization of the GPU's Encoding/Decoding resources

If the encoding/decoding utilization is consistently near 100%, it may indicate that the GPU is being overutilized.
panels.title: GPU Encode/Decode Utilization

panels.description:
This displays the current amount of free framebuffer memory available on the GPU.

Green = < 50%
Yellow = > 50%
Red = > 80%
panels.title: GPU Free Memory not in use

panels.description: This measures the total capacity of the GPU
panels.title: GPU Max Capacity

panels.description:
This chart displays the distinct types of stream errors that occur, along with their corresponding counts within a 1-hour period:

0-3 counts: Needs Minor Attention

4-9 counts: Needs Medium Attention

10 or more counts: Needs Urgent Attention

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
    `toStartOfHour`(`toTimeZone`(`source`.`timestamp_ts`, 'UTC')) AS `timestamp_ts`,
    `source`.`short_message` AS `short_message`,
    COUNT(*) AS `count`
FROM (
    SELECT
        `network_events`.`stream_events`.`sub_type` AS `sub_type`,
        `network_events`.`stream_events`.`timestamp_ts` AS `timestamp_ts`,
        `network_events`.`stream_events`.`message` AS `message`,
        `substring`(`toString`(`network_events`.`stream_events`.`message`), 1, 70) AS `short_message`
    FROM
        `network_events`.`stream_events`
    WHERE
        `network_events`.`stream_events`.`sub_type` = 'error'
) AS `source`
WHERE
    `source`.`short_message` != ''
GROUP BY
    `toStartOfHour`(`toTimeZone`(`source`.`timestamp_ts`, 'UTC')),
    `source`.`short_message`
HAVING
    COUNT(*) >= 5  -- Filter for counts of 5 or more
ORDER BY
    `toStartOfHour`(`toTimeZone`(`source`.`timestamp_ts`, 'UTC')) DESC,
    `source`.`short_message` DESC
LIMIT 20;

panels.title: Error count by type Per hour

panels.description:
This chart visualizes the counts of 'restart' and 'error' events occurring in a stream over time

Restart Count: This metric indicates the number of times a 'restart' event occurred within the specified minute. A higher count may suggest frequent restarts, which could indicate potential issues with service stability or performance.

Error Count: This metric represents the number of 'error' events logged during the same minute. An increase in error counts may signal underlying problems that require investigation, such as system failures or misconfigurations.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
    toStartOfMinute(se.timestamp_ts) AS timestamp_ts,
    ss.state,
    sum(se.restart_count) AS Restart_Count,
    countIf(se.sub_type = 'error') AS Error_Count       
FROM 
    network_events.stream_events AS se
JOIN 
    network_events.stream_status AS ss ON se.stream_id = ss.stream_id
WHERE 
    se.stream_id IN (SELECT DISTINCT stream_id FROM network_events.stream_events)
    AND $__timeFilter(se.timestamp_ts)
GROUP BY 
    timestamp_ts, ss.state
ORDER BY 
    timestamp_ts ASC;

panels.title: Stream Health Status

panels.description:
FPS(Frame Per Seconds) 

AVG Output < 10 :- Needs investigation

AVG Output between 10 -15 :-  Needs to be monitored closely

AVG Output equals to or greater than 15 :- Good Health

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
  `network_events`.`stream_status`.`stream_id` AS `stream_id`,
  AVG(`network_events`.`stream_status`.`output_fps`) AS `avg`
FROM
  `network_events`.`stream_status`
WHERE
  (
    `network_events`.`stream_status`.`timestamp_ts` >= `toStartOfHour`((`now64`(9, 'UTC') + INTERVAL -24 hour))
  )
  AND (
    `network_events`.`stream_status`.`timestamp_ts` < `toStartOfHour`((`now64`(9, 'UTC') + INTERVAL 1 hour))
  )
  AND (
    `network_events`.`stream_status`.`pipeline` = 'comfyui'
  )
GROUP BY
  `network_events`.`stream_status`.`stream_id`
HAVING
  AVG(`network_events`.`stream_status`.`output_fps`) < 10
ORDER BY
  `avg` ASC,
  `network_events`.`stream_status`.`stream_id` ASC
LIMIT 60;

panels.title: FPS Output

list.definition: SELECT DISTINCT stream_id FROM network_events.stream_events where $__timeFilter(timestamp_ts)
list.label: Select Stream ID
list.name: stream_id
list.query: SELECT DISTINCT stream_id FROM network_events.stream_events where $__timeFilter(timestamp_ts)

list.definition:
SELECT DISTINCT Streams.stream_key
FROM network_events.stream_events
LEFT JOIN network_events.streams AS Streams ON stream_events.stream_id = Streams.id
WHERE $__timeFilter(timestamp_ts);
list.label: Stream Key
list.name: stream_key
list.query:
SELECT DISTINCT Streams.stream_key
FROM network_events.stream_events
LEFT JOIN network_events.streams AS Streams ON stream_events.stream_id = Streams.id
WHERE $__timeFilter(timestamp_ts);
